articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website

articles.title: Dissertation Info
articles.contents:
Contents
Important Dates
A Very Rough Timeline
Analysis Plan
Working with Secondary Data

Important Dates
Ethics: week 8
Analysis plan: Dec
First draft & feedback: TBD
Dissertation standard deadline: May 2022
A Very Rough Timeline
Oct: Read up on topic area, decide on research question, hypotheses and methodology
Nov: Prepare materials, refine method and submit ethics
Dec: Do analysis plan, start data collection and draft method section
Jan: Continue data collection, start on analysis and draft intro
Feb: Draft results and discussion
March: Feedback on first draft
April: Final edits
May: Submit!! ü•≥
Analysis Plan
An analysis plan is a very useful tool that helps you to ensure that your method is appropriate to test your hypotheses. By thinking about your analysis in advance, you can better anticipate any problems with your design that could negatively impact the quality of your data. Writing up the method section of your dissertation is also much easier when you have already completed an analysis plan that you can refer back to. You should complete the Dissertation Analysis Plan prior to collecting any data.
Working with Secondary Data
Coming Soon!

articles.title: ErroR Search
articles.description: This page includes a list of common R errors, their usual causes, and some solutions!
articles.contents:
Contents
Could not find function ".."
Could not find function "%>%"

Coming Soon!
Could not find function ".."
This error usually occurs because the package which contains the function isn‚Äôt loaded or the function isn‚Äôt spelled correctly.
Solutions
Check the package is loaded with library(package)
Check the function is spelled correctly
Could not find function "%>%"
This error occurs because the magrittr package which contains the pipe operator %>% isn‚Äôt loaded.
Solutions
Load the package with library(magrittr) or library(tidyverse)

More coming soon!

articles.title: R Resources
articles.description: This page contains links to R resources & tutorials for each core topic covered in PAAS, AnD, DS & QQM
articles.contents:
Contents
Accessing Tutorials
R, RStudio & General Computing
R Markdown
Importing & Organising Data
Inspecting, Cleaning & Wrangling Data
Summarising Data
Statistical Analyses
Reporting Results

Accessing Tutorials
Much of the R content is delivered through interactive tutorials. These tutorials need to be installed & run within RStudio. To install the packages required to run them (‚Äúlearnr‚Äù, ‚Äúremotes‚Äù, ‚Äúpaas‚Äù, & ‚Äúdiscovr‚Äù), type each of the commands in the code block below into the RStudio console one at a time and press Enter to run them.
Following installation, tutorials can be accessed through the ‚ÄúTutorial‚Äù tab in RStudio, or by running the relevant code in the console.


install.packages("learnr")
install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("SussexPsychMethods/PAAS", build = FALSE, upgrade = "never")
remotes::install_github("profandyfield/discovr")



Most R skills are covered in several modules & in several tutorials/practicals. Where this repetition occurs, there are multiple resources to refer to for help!

R, RStudio & General Computing
Installation of R & RStudio: PAAS 00
Tours of RStudio: PAAS 01
File paths:


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "02_files_paths_projects", package = "paas")



R Projects: PAAS 03, PAAS 08
R objects, functions & packages: PAAS 05, PAAS 06, PAAS 07, PAAS 07


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "04_basic_r", package = "paas")





learnr::run_tutorial(name = "05_objects_functions_data", package = "paas")





learnr::run_tutorial(name = "06_functions_packages", package = "paas")





learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_01", package = "discovr")




R Markdown
Basic R Markdown: PAAS 04


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "03_r_markdown", package = "paas")



Advanced R Markdown: AnD 01

Importing & Organising Data
Import tidy data:


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "07_organizing_data", package = "paas")




Inspecting, Cleaning & Wrangling Data
Inspecting data: AnD 03
Wrangling data: PAAS 09


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "08_wrangling_data", package = "paas")



The pipe %>% PAAS 10, AnD 02


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "09_summaries_and_pipes", package = "paas")



Data cleaning: AnD 03, AnD 04
Creating composites: AnD 07
Checking dodgy data:


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_06", package = "discovr")



Centring variables:


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_10", package = "discovr")




Summarising Data
Basic summary tables: PAAS 10, AnD 03


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "09_summaries_and_pipes", package = "paas")



Pretty tables: PAAS 11
Plots: PAAS 11, AnD


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_05", package = "discovr")



Summary stats & CIs:


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_02", package = "discovr")





learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_03", package = "discovr")




Statistical Analyses
Correlation: AnD 05


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_07", package = "discovr")



Chi-Square: AnD 06
t-test: AnD 07


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_09", package = "discovr")



Linear model: AnD 08, AnD 09, AnD 10, AnD 11


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_08", package = "discovr")





learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_11", package = "discovr")





learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_12", package = "discovr")





learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_13", package = "discovr")





learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_14", package = "discovr")





learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_15", package = "discovr")



Moderation & mediation:


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_10", package = "discovr")



Exploratory factor analysis:


learnr::run_tutorial(name = "discovr_18", package = "discovr")




Reporting Results
Inline code: AnD 05

articles.title: Journal Club
articles.description: Share any interesting articles and helpful resources!
articles.contents:
Contents
Submit Your Article
Educational Outcomes üìö
Gamification üéÆüëæ & Stats Education üìä
General Cool Stuff ü§©

Submit Your Article

Click to submit!

Loading‚Ä¶

Educational Outcomes üìö
Evans, D., & Field, A. P. (2020). Maths attitudes, school affect and teacher characteristics as predictors of maths attainment trajectories in primary and secondary education. Royal Society Open Science, 7(10), 200975.
Evans, D., & Field, A. P. (2020). Predictors of mathematical attainment trajectories across the primary-to-secondary education transition: Parental factors and the home environment. Royal Society Open Science, 7(7), 200422.
Evans, D., Gaysina, D., & Field, A. P. (2020). Internalizing symptoms and working memory as predictors of mathematical attainment trajectories across the primary‚Äìsecondary education transition. Royal Society Open Science, 7(5), 191433.
Field, A. P., Evans, D., Bloniewski, T., & Kovas, Y. (2019). Predicting maths anxiety from mathematical achievement across the transition from primary to secondary education. Royal Society Open Science, 6(11), 191459.
Evans, D., Borriello, G. A., & Field, A. P. (2018). A review of the academic and psychological impact of the transition to secondary education. Frontiers in Psychology, 9.
Gamification üéÆüëæ & Stats Education üìä
Christy, K. R., & Fox, J. (2014). Leaderboards in a virtual classroom: A test of stereotype threat and social comparison explanations for women‚Äôs math performance. Computers & Education, 78, 66-77.
Field, A. P. & Terry, J. C. (2018). A pilot study of whether fictional narratives are useful in teaching statistical concepts.
Jia, Y., Xu, B., Karanam, Y., & Voida, S. (2016). Personality-targeted gamification: a survey study on personality traits and motivational affordances. In Proceedings of the 2016 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, 2001-2013.
Landers, R. N., Bauer, K. N., & Callan, R. C. (2017). Gamification of task performance with leaderboards: A goal setting experiment. Computers in Human Behavior, 71, 508-515.
Mekler, E. D., Br√ºhlmann, F., Tuch, A. N., & Opwis, K. (2017). Towards understanding the effects of individual gamification elements on intrinsic motivation and performance. Computers in Human Behavior, 71, 525-534.
Sailer, M., & Homner, L. (2020). The gamification of learning: A meta-analysis. Educational Psychology Review, 32, 77‚Äì112.
Smith, T. (2017). Gamified Modules for an Introductory Statistics Course and Their Impact on Attitudes and Learning. Simulation & Gaming, 48(6), 832‚Äì854.
General Cool Stuff ü§©

Contents

Accessing Tutorials
Most R skills are covered in several tutorials/practicals in different modules. Where this repetition occurs, there are multiple resources to refer to for help.
Some of these R resources include interactive tutorials. These tutorials need to be installed & run within RStudio. To install the packages required to run them (‚Äúlearnr‚Äù, ‚Äúremotes‚Äù, ‚Äúpaas‚Äù, & ‚Äúdiscovr‚Äù), type each of the commands in the code block below into the RStudio console one at a time and press Enter to run them.


install.packages("learnr")
install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("SussexPsychMethods/PAAS", build = FALSE, upgrade = "never")
remotes::install_github("profandyfield/discovr")



Following installation, tutorials can be accessed through the ‚ÄúTutorial‚Äù tab in RStudio, or by running the relevant code in the console, i.e.,


learnr::run_tutorial("discovr_01", package = "discovr")

articles.title: Writing a Dissertation in RMarkdown
articles.description: Work through this tutorial & the task boxes to help you get started with writing your dissertation in RMarkdown!
articles.contents:
Contents
Workflow
Installing papaja
Using papaja
YAML Options
Referencing & .bib files
Inserting Student Support Stickers in R
& that‚Äôs all there is to it! üíÉ ü•≥

Workflow
The best way to work within R is to create an R Project for each specific project you work on. This idea applies to your dissertation too where it‚Äôs best to create an R Project solely for your dissertation.

Create a dissertation R Project in a sensible location on your device

You should use this newly created R Project for all dissertation related files to keep everything all in one place and nicely organised.
You should then aim to create the following folders:
data
r_docs
misc_docs
references
Within these folders, data should contain any raw data, r_docs should contain any Rmds or R scripts, misc_docs (or just docs if you prefer) should contain any documents not created in RStudio such as ethics forms, and references should contain saved copies of articles you have read and will cite in your writeup, and .bib files (more on these later..). You don‚Äôt have to follow this workflow at all, but you might find it helpful to structure your files in this way so that things don‚Äôt get muddled!

Within the R Project you‚Äôve just created, create 4 folders to contain your data, r_docs, misc_docs, and references (or use whichever names you prefer)


Installing papaja
papaja is an R package that contains an Rmd template for producing APA style reports. It‚Äôs what I recommend to use when writing up your dissertation in RMarkdown to create a pretty report when you knit your document (it‚Äôs also what I wrote my PhD thesis with & is one of my fave packages, in close competition with the BRRR package - seriously, go check it out right now! üòé).
With papaja you can knit your Rmd to a pdf or word document so you can use whichever format you prefer, and it‚Äôs just a really nice way of creating reproducible analyses that are super pretty with your report automatically formatted in APA style - a total win-win!
It‚Äôs best to install papaja as soon as possible in the semester (ideally week 1) so that I can troubleshoot any problems early on. The following steps will guide you through the installation process.
Step 1: install a TeX distribution
LaTeX is needed when knitting from an Rmd to a pdf document. Installing a TeX distribution on your device is arguably the worst part of the installation process. For more info see the installation details..
To install it in RStudio, you can run the following lines in the console:


if(!"tinytex" %in% rownames(installed.packages())) install.packages("tinytex")





tinytex::install_tinytex()



Step 2: install papaja
Installing the papaja package is more straightforward, firstly we need to check that we have devtools installed (the first line below), and secondly we need to install papaja from github rather than from the cran (the second line).


if(!"devtools" %in% rownames(installed.packages())) install.packages("devtools")





devtools::install_github("crsh/papaja")




Install tinytex and papaja using the code above!


Using papaja
Once everything‚Äôs installed, the Rmd template from the papaja package can be easily accessed through the main menu. To open the template go to File > New File > R Markdown‚Ä¶ in the window that pops up, click on From Template > APA article (6th edition) > OK

Open the APA article template using the instructions above

This template is very similar to the standard Rmd that you‚Äôre used to working with previously. The template still contains three main components:
The YAML for document metadata
R Code Chunks for code
Markdown for your main writeup
The main difference between this template and a normal Rmd is that the YAML just contains some additional options.

Knit the document as it is to check it all works!

After knitting, you should have an APA style article magically appear! ü§©

Your dissertation should be submitted with the file name: cand_no_report
When creating the Rmd for your dissertation writeup, save it with this file name from the start to avoid any issues later on & remember to save it in the r_docs folder of your R Project as suggested in the workflow


YAML Options
You might notice in the Rmd that there are quite a few extra YAML options we can set that will change various parts of the document. Some of these options are more useful/relevant than others so I‚Äôve included the main ones you‚Äôll be using below, and the rest you can delete from the YAML.




To avoid more errors & to check your wordcount & spelling more accurately, I recommend knitting to a Word doc
This is easily changed in the final line of the YAML above!


Referencing & .bib files
To automatically reference articles/books/other sources in RMarkdown, the setup is slightly different to what you will have used previously. Instead, we use BibTeX references which we include within a .bib file that we specify in the YAML of our Rmd (see image above). There are many pros to using this approach in that you don‚Äôt ever have to worry again about formatting your in-text citations to APA style, and that your reference list is automatically generated and formatted (amazing right?!)
These files can feel (& look) a little confusing to start with but I personally find it much better this way than what I did before and once you get the hang of it it‚Äôs much quicker!
To create a .bib file it‚Äôs super easy, just follow the steps below!

In your dissertation R Project, open up your working directory by going to the Files Pane > More > Show Folder in New Window

If you completed the task box above, your dissertation R Project folder should now open.

In this folder, open a new plain text document by right-click > New > Text Document & name it diss_references (or whatever you prefer)
Once created, rename the file to have a .bib extension rather than a .txt extension & you will have created your .bib file!
Then move this file to the references folder of your R Project to keep with the workflow


OK, so now we have created our .bib file, there are two things we need to do:
Add this file path to the bibliography part of the YAML in our Rmd
Add some references
For step 1, it‚Äôs nice and simple, we just need to include the file path like the example below:




Add the .bib file you just created to the YAML


Now we need to add some references to our .bib file!
BibTeX references look like this:



Where ‚Äúarticle‚Äù is the type of the source, ‚Äúevans2020internalizing‚Äù is the label, and the remaining fields refer to the different components of a bibliography item. The BibTeX references of articles are given on many journal webpages, but the easiest way to get them IMO is by using the Google Scholar Button for Chrome (see the steps below).




Search for a relevant article & copy/paste the entry to your .bib file (you can open the .bib file in RStudio)


& finally we need to insert the references to the Rmd!
There are two ways of inserting references, you can do it manually by inputting the BibTeX label, or you can use the citr RStudio add-in which allows you to search for the reference from the .bib file.
To insert them by hand, it‚Äôs super straightforward, the table below (taken from the papaja manual) shows you how to include the reference label and what will be shown in the knitted file.




Alternatively, you can use the citr addin to search for the references in your .bib file. Within RStudio, find the ‚ÄúAddins‚Äù menu underneath the Tools & Help buttons, citr can be accessed from there.





You will see a ‚ÄúReferences‚Äù section at the end of the papaja template, you don‚Äôt need to edit this, just leave it as it is - everything is automatic!


Referencing R Packages
You will see the below code in the papaja Rmd template. What this does is automatically include any packages you use within the references section. You don‚Äôt need to edit this in anyway, just leave as it is and remember to cite the R packages you use for analysis in the method/results section of your report.


library("papaja")
r_refs("r-references.bib")




Inserting Student Support Stickers in R
Including a student support sticker when writing your dissertation in R is super straightforward; you can use the code below modifying the file path to where your sticker is saved (this could be in the misc_docs folder of your R Project for example), and should be included in a code chunk in the most appropriate section of your Rmd.


knitr::include_graphics("path_to_file")




& that‚Äôs all there is to it! üíÉ ü•≥
You can now start writing up your dissertation in RMarkdown woohoo!
There are a few things to keep in mind to make this process easier:
Knit often and after any major additions/changes, errors can be tricky to solve so knitting often will help you catch where problems occur
Make sure your file knits before you leave it for the day, it‚Äôs better to work on knitting problems whilst everything you‚Äôve been working on is fresh in your mind
Make sure your references are complete and correct as you go - don‚Äôt leave it until you have 100 references to go back to and check the page numbers of
By default, papaja sets global chunk options to echo = F (code is run but hidden) & messages = F, sometimes you might want to set warnings = F too
papaja reports all numeric values written using inline code to 2 dp by default
To report any equations in your Rmd, enclose it within $
References of ‚Äò???‚Äô highlight errors, check the entry exists in your .bib file & check the spelling of it in your Rmd
Remember that no duplicate chunk labels are allowed - this will cause an error
Don‚Äôt install packages in your code chunks - use the console
Google really is your best friend for any errors
Try to troubleshoot problems yourself before coming to me - I‚Äôm here to help and support you but your dissertation is an independent research project after all

& Finally, Good Luck! üåü

articles.title: R Thesis Template
articles.contents:
sussexthesis package
The sussexthesis package is based on Chester Ismay‚Äôs thesisdown package. The package includes a thesis template that is designed to be compatible with the submission requirements of the University of Sussex, with some additional APA formatting. The package is under active development and currently only works when knitting to pdf.

Using sussexthesis
Follow the thesisdown setup guide before installing sussexthesis package as detailed below:


# Install devtools
install.packages("devtools")
library(devtools)

# Install sussexthesis
devtools::install_github("de84sussex/sussexthesis")
library(sussexthesis)



Tips & Tricks
A user guide is given in the index.Rmd file & describes how to use the template
Some additional tips for correctly using headings are given in the 01-chap1.Rmd file
The formatting is applied automatically, but you can hack it by using LaTeX & Markdown in the file you wish to edit
The package is somewhat experimental, if you run into any problems please let me know!

articles.title: End of SemestR TestR
articles.description: Test your knowledge & identify areas to revise!
articles.contents:
Contents
The End of SemestR TestR

Coming soon!
The End of SemestR TestR is a (fun) quiz to check how much you‚Äôve leaRnt this semester, to see what skills you‚Äôre a total supeRstaR at, & to help you identify which topics to revise. The quiz covers the fundRmentals of R/RStudio & the key functions we‚Äôve covered in the past semester. Your answers will be saved in your browser so you can come back to it later if you wish!

The End of SemestR TestR





  iFrameResize({}, ".interactive");
